• The housing's air inlet side can extend radially outward, maintaining the air outlet side's structure for consistent heat dissipation.

• The heat-dissipating device can include an impeller with blade dimensions increased along with the outward extension of the housing.

• The system includes a casing, electrical elements, and the heat-dissipating device, with the latter enhancing heat dissipation efficiency.

• The heat sink can be assembled with the housing, guiding air streams towards the heat source's central portion for optimal cooling.

• The design allows for increased airflow and heat dissipation, with the inclined sidewall passage effectively concentrating air streams for better heat sink cooling.

• The outward extension of the housing's sidewall significantly improves heat dissipation efficiency without changing the fan's assembly conditions with other elements.

• The dimensions of the heat-dissipating fan's blades can be enlarged along with the outward extension of the housing, increasing airflow and heat dissipation.

• The passage formed by the sidewall of the housing has a gradually reduced inner diameter, effectively concentrating air streams towards the heat sink's central portion.

• The heat-dissipating device can be mounted within a system casing, dissipating heat generated by electrical elements during operation.

• The design of the inclined portion of the sidewall of the passage of the heat-dissipating device guides air streams towards the central portion of the heat sink, enhancing heat dissipation effects.

• The outward extension of the sidewall of the housing and the design of the inclined portion of the passage contribute to increased airflow and enhanced heat dissipation efficiency.

* The electroluminescent display panel of the invention is designed to display different colors based on voltage levels, eliminating the need for an intermediate electrode.
* It consists of various layers on a glass substrate, including electrode layers, insulation layers, and luminescent layers, arranged in a matrix for picture elements.
* The first luminescent layer emits green light, while the second layer, partly overlapping the first, emits orange light, forming a lemon color at higher voltages.
* This panel is suitable for use as an instrument panel in vehicles, displaying green at night and lemon at day, enhancing visibility and comfort.
* The structure is simple, reducing cost, and the display can be customized for different applications by adjusting the luminescent materials and patterns.

• The invention relates to an electronic portable communications terminal for Internet/network telephony, which uses a network and/or the Internet for transferring information/data representing digitized speech, sounds, music, etc. The terminal comprises audio means for reproducing and recording sound, converting means for converting second electrical signals into transmission data and vice versa, and protocol means for handling and controlling communication in accordance with a standardized Internet/network protocol.

• The terminal further comprises wireless communications means for establishing a wireless connection to a connecting unit, which allows the terminal to establish a connection to a network and/or the Internet. The wireless communications means embeds and extracts packets of data packet format in/from the wireless data format, enabling the terminal to communicate with the connecting unit for transferring data packets to the network or Internet.

• The invention utilizes a germanium buffer layer between high-dielectric oxides and substrates like silicon or metals to prevent oxidation and enhance epitaxy, improving the integration of ferroelectrics and other large dielectric constant materials. This method also allows for the direct deposition of ferroelectrics on silicon wafers for non-volatile, non-destructive readout memory cells.

• A second buffer layer of a stable high-dielectric oxide, such as SrTiO3, can be used between a Pb-containing ferroelectric and the germanium layer to control Pb diffusion. This setup facilitates the deposition of various stable ferroelectrics, including those with high dielectric constants, on GaAs and other III-V compounds, enhancing their use in semiconductor circuitry applications.

* The invention addresses the issue of signal distortion in receiver input circuits, aiming for a balance between small and large signal behavior and cost-effective production.
* It proposes a receiver input circuit with multiple amplification control loops, each serving distinct purposes in protecting components from overloading and ensuring signal integrity.
* The first control loop, derived from the intermediate frequency signal, prevents unwanted overloading of the mixer stage and varactor diodes.
* The second loop, with a narrower band width, avoids overloading the mixer stage and oscillator due to strong signals.
* The third loop, with the lowest response threshold and band width, supports the other control circuits or adjusts amplification based on spurious signals.
* An embodiment of the input circuit includes a PIN diode for controllable signal attenuation, protected by a buffer amplifier if necessary.
* The circuit design ensures minimal change in operating current during control, reducing temperature variations in integrated circuits.
* The use of extended reactance networks enhances control range and selectivity, avoiding strong attenuation during tuning.
* Separate supply and adjustment of tuning voltage for varactor diodes enable iteration-free alignment of all tunable circuits in the receiver input.
* An embodiment with a single twin varactor diode ensures high identity in the C(U) characteristic, simplifying adjustment and improving tuning consistency.

* The invention relates to network implemented shared workspace environments, specifically for spontaneously setting up collaborative work-sharing between physically distant individuals.
* The background discusses traditional collaborative tools like video conferencing, document sharing, and whiteboard systems, often used in dedicated conference rooms or on personal computers.
* The summary highlights the challenges of current PC-based products, including complex setup processes and lack of intrinsic voice communication during setup.
* The invention proposes a system for initiating a collaborative work-share environment through a telephone call, using a collaboration button and indicator to simplify setup and maintain voice communication.
* The system allows for enhanced communication via desktop collaboration applications, such as video conferencing and document sharing, without the need for complex setup or dedicated equipment.

* The invention relates to enhancing the visual impact of advertising clips inserted into video sequences by accounting for the continuity of regions of interest.
* A method is proposed to process pictures, selecting an advertising clip that optimally matches the video sequence before an insertion point, typically a shot change, for seamless integration.
* The device for processing pictures includes means for generating salience maps, determining similarity, selecting the most suitable clip, and inserting it into the video sequence at the defined point.
* The method and device aim to improve viewer perception of advertising content by ensuring a smooth transition, enhancing overall viewer experience and ad impact.

• The invention introduces a recessed mask structure to prevent localized high electrical fields at intersections in very small dimension semiconductor devices, aiming to reduce electrical breakdown and enhance device performance in high-speed and high-density integrated circuits.

• The technology utilizes a differentiating or mask member positioned below the surface to be planarized, at a distance of about 0.5 to 20 nanometers, to lower the electric field and achieve reduced lateral leakage current and a lower effective dielectric constant compared to conventional structures.

• The invention is particularly useful in damascene type device structures, where it assists in patterning thin trenches in interlevel dielectric materials, protects the dielectric during processing, and aids in the fabrication of interconnects with fine metal features and low dielectric constant insulators.

* The Downconverting Digitizer invention utilizes predictive coding principles for implementing a simple down converting A/D converter, reducing complexity and enhancing performance.
* It places the sampler inside the predictive loop, enabling digital implementation of the filter and improving dynamic range and noise performance.
* The invention operates in a subharmonic mode, downconverting the signal and simplifying digital logic implementation.
* The digital predictive loop output controls the gain of the input signal, enhancing dynamic range.
* An offset nuller element corrects for biases introduced by implementation imperfections, improving DC offset performance.
* The invention outperforms prior art in dynamic range, detection bandwidth, and cost-effectiveness, addressing challenges in analog-to-digital conversion.

* The invention relates to active solid state devices, specifically sensors with nanodimensional features for detecting molecular compounds, organisms, or gas molecules. It utilizes nanowires and nanotubes for high-sensitivity detection due to charge carrier depletion or accumulation affecting the conduction pathway.
* Nanoimprint lithography is employed to fabricate groups of semiconducting nanotraces between electrodes, which can be used as sensors or for multiplex detection of analytes. This method provides a controllable and regular pattern of semiconducting electrode "nanotraces" in a single processing step, enabling detection of gases adsorbed on semiconductor surfaces or multiplex detection of many simultaneous detection zones.
* The multiplex detection array consists of six individual sensor devices, each with a set of two interdigitated electrodes and a third gate electrode. Semiconductor nanotraces are patterned using nanoimprint lithography, providing narrow electrical bridges between the electrodes. The response to changes in the local environment is proportional to the degree of influence on the electrical current traversing the set of semiconductor nanotraces, facilitating detection of target molecules.

• The present invention provides a method for singulating and plating semiconductor packages, focusing on plating the side surfaces of leads to prevent contamination and improve soldering results.

• The method involves providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a leadframe, singulating the dies, and then plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads, which can be copper, with a plating material such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.

• The invention can employ full cutting, where the leadframe is completely cut in one operation, or partial cutting, which involves multiple steps including partial cuts and full cuts, to achieve desired side surface shapes and heights.

* The invention relates to a dual mode mobile terminal for selectively connecting to a wireless wide area network and a wireless local network.
* It provides a method for a mobile terminal to select a serving base station of a wireless wide area network in a communication system.
* The system contains a mobile terminal, a wireless wide area network, and a wireless local area network.
* The mobile terminal has a first wireless module for connecting the WWAN and a second wireless module for connecting the WLAN.
* The method involves turning the first wireless module on according to a first rule, receiving service information from the second base station, transmitting the service information to the first wireless module, and selecting a serving base station according to the service information.
* This invention aims to avoid dropping or delaying connections by efficiently switching from the WLAN to the WWAN.

* The invention relates to the production of multilayered components, particularly multilayer capacitors, through a simplified process.
* The conventional process involves casting a ceramic slip, printing electrodes, stacking and laminating, cutting, thermal processing, and metallizing.
* The new process eliminates cutting and metallizing steps, simplifying the manufacturing of multilayered components.
* It includes providing electrodes and components, locating them in recesses, stacking sub-assemblies, and forming a resultant assembly.
* The process allows for the use of multiple electrodes and components on decals, facilitating precise registration and assembly.
* It enables the interconnection of electrodes in stacked sub-assemblies, building-up stacks with covering components, and fabricating assemblies of various sizes.
* The apparatus includes decals, screening equipment, and tools for manipulation and assembly of sub-assemblies.
* The method provides for in-process inspection, use of thinner dielectrics, and the elimination of cutting stress cracks.
* Advantages include smaller part sizes, lower voltage ratings, no shape limitations, enhanced inspection, and reduced labor content.
* The process is adaptable for manufacturing other electronic ceramic devices, such as multilayer ferrite inductors and multilayer substrates.
* It enables the production of electrical coils, transformers, magnetic amplifiers, saturable reactors, solenoids, memory cores, and semiconductor packages.
* The invention facilitates the fabrication of precision registers and series connected components, including resistors, coils, and capacitors in one stack.

• The invention relates to cellular materials with hierarchical cellular lattices for structural applications.
• Sandwich panels are used in various industries, including transportation, ballistics, and construction.
• The core of the sandwich panels comprises a lattice structure with a network of hierarchical trusses.
• The lattice structure utilizes cells of various sizes, nested and mated to provide high stiffness and strength.
• The core can be balanced or mated with another lattice structure to form a sandwich panel.
• Panels can be attached to the core or lattice structure for applications in floors, walls, and vehicles.
• The lattice structures can be made from polymers, metals, or other materials through injection molding or other processes.
• The structures can be used for impact or blast energy absorption, heat exchange, and as armors.
• Various methods and compositions are disclosed for manufacturing the lattice structures and cores.
• The invention encompasses a wide range of modifications and equivalents within the scope of the claims.

• The invention provides an integrated process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons, combining a coal-to-liquid (CTL) facility and an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) facility. 

• The CTL facility includes a dry gasification stage for producing synthesis gas precursor, a wet gasification stage for enriching the gas, and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis stages for converting the gas to hydrocarbons. 

• The IGCC facility utilizes a wet gasification stage for producing combustion gas, a sour shift stage for enriching the gas, and a gas combustion and expansion stage for generating power. 

• The process optimally utilizes both dry and wet gasification technologies, enhancing energy efficiency and providing suitable streams for power production and hydrocarbon synthesis.

* The present invention provides a method for preparing a superconducting device with improved surface properties for oxide superconducting materials. This is achieved by uniformly coating a blocking film over the surface or micro-holes of the superconducting material to prevent oxygen removal, ensuring consistent conductivity characteristics across the material.
* The blocking film, which can be an insulating or half-insulating material, is formed using a photo CVD method to effectively cover the internal surfaces of the superconducting material. Oxygen is then added to the surface or portion close to it, and the entire body is heat treated to position the added oxygen in the appropriate atom location, converting the film into a highly dense insulating material.

• The invention provides an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination, focusing on foam sheet stock suitable for container manufacture, which is difficult to sever without damaging the delicate cell structure.

• The apparatus includes a base structure, a clamping arrangement to grasp the foam sheet without damaging it, and a screw thread specimen advance mechanism to prepare repetitive, uniform thickness samples with parallel cut edges for detailed examination.

• The method ensures precise cutting and parallel orientation of the foam samples, facilitating accurate microscopic analysis of the cell structure and integrity of the foam sheet material.

* The invention relates to determining the angle of inclination of seismometers, especially those on ocean floors, and leveling their seismic motion detectors.
* Seismometers are crucial for geological research, particularly in oil and natural gas exploration.
* Ocean bottom seismometers (OBS) are designed for remote operation on ocean floors, facing challenges in positioning and orientation.
* The method and apparatus determine the angle of inclination by suspending a seismic motion detector as a free-moving pendulum.
* A spring-loaded plunger, restrained by a pin, is used to lock the detector in place after deployment.
* The plunger is automatically released by a solenoid, allowing the detector to lock in its position.
* The angle of inclination is measured by the acute angle formed between the locked position and the vertical when the seismometer is upright.
* The invention provides a simple, inexpensive way to level seismic motion detectors and determine the angle of inclination.
* The apparatus includes a mounting plate, a plunger, a spring, and a solenoid for automatic leveling and angle measurement.
* The system ensures good coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector, improving seismic wave recording.

• The invention introduces a humidity sensing element that responds to moisture changes quickly, without mechanical movements, and is physically robust, requiring no special protection. It provides accurate humidity measurement, unlike previous elements, and is manufactured using a combination of familiar manufacturing techniques.

• The humidity sensing element consists of a first conductive electrode, a porous dielectric coating, minute conductive particles within the dielectric, a second conductive and moisture-permeable electrode, and an ion-forming material that reduces dielectric porosity. The impedance between electrodes varies linearly with relative humidity when excited by an alternating current voltage.

• The preferred embodiment uses 99.4% pure aluminum for the first electrode, anodizes it to form the dielectric, deposits nickel particles in the dielectric's interstices, hydrolizes and seals the anodized layer, and then deposits a second nickel electrode. The sensor is suitable for 10 Hz AC voltage excitation for optimal linearity in humidity sensing.

* The invention provides a force transmission structure for a motor assembly, focusing on a drive plate and a shaft.
* The drive plate features a mounting hole with at least three interconnected sections, allowing a shaft with a toothed portion to fit precisely, ensuring stable rotation.
* The shaft includes a pinion for driving a window lift system's gear, and the drive plate is made of plastics for better vibration absorption and noise reduction.
* The motor assembly, incorporating the force transmission structure, improves upon conventional designs by enhancing stability, torque capacity, and noise reduction through its innovative components and materials.

• The invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver, focusing on detection, identification, and monitoring of multipath signals in WCDMA systems.
• The system comprises an antenna, radio frequency subsystem, and baseband subsystem, with the baseband subsystem featuring a free running counter that uses a high frequency oscillator for wake mode and a low frequency oscillator for sleep mode.
• The free running counter maintains a mobile time reference with an accuracy of approximately 32 nanoseconds, crucial for efficient multipath signal processing in 3G wireless communication.
• The method involves providing high and low frequency clocks, generating a mobile time reference using the high frequency clock, maintaining it with the low frequency clock during unavailability, and continuing with the high frequency clock when available.
• The low frequency clock is phase-locked to the high frequency clock, and drift/bias estimation is made using Kalman filtering for accurate time reference maintenance during sleep mode.
• The mobile time reference is essential for signal timing, processing, and storage functions in portable transceivers, enabling quick transitions between active and idle states to conserve power.
• The system's multipath monitoring and recovery circuit includes components like primary sync searcher, secondary sync searcher, gold code searcher, and multipath radio signal recovery circuit, enhancing signal efficiency and quality in wideband spread spectrum communications.

* Protective helmets with hard outer shells are well known in the art.
* Resilient liner assemblies are desirable for shock absorption.
* Adjustable straps are commonly used but can cause wobbling.
* Custom-fitted liner assemblies have been proposed to overcome this issue.
* Direct handling of foaming agents limits the utility of some methods in the field.
* Preformed liners with complex structures limit practical application and are one-shot procedures.
* The Lavender application discloses an individually fitted helmet liner with thermoplastic sheets and hollow epoxy balloon spacer elements.
* The helmet liner described in the Lavender application fulfills its inventor's objects but has certain areas for improvement.
* The invention aims to provide a helmet liner that can be fitted rapidly and simply to a wearer's head.
* The liner is designed to be refitted to accommodate a changed head size without requiring trimming afterward.
* The liner is relatively simple and inexpensive to manufacture, resisting the tendency to shift position on the wearer's head.

• The invention is a multiorifice wafer structure for atomizing fuel in automotive engines, featuring a plurality of angularly disposed passages.

• The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods and cylindrical members, with each layer's rods disposed at progressively larger angles relative to the axis.

• The fused assembly is cut into thin wafers, creating angularly disposed passageways that increase in angle from the center, enhancing atomization.

• The object is a multiorifice structure with angularly disposed passageways, improving fuel dispersion in engines.

• The method involves fusing alternating layers of rods and cylindrical members, slicing the assembly to produce the desired spray plate.

• The invention aims to provide a cost-effective, high-volume solution for automotive fuel injector valves, overcoming limitations of prior art techniques.

* The text describes a method for fabricating a semiconductor device, particularly an insulated gate (MOS) field effect device with a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
* The process involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, depositing a conductive layer, anisotropically etching it to leave a portion on the gate sidewall, and then forming the LDD structure.
* The method improves the controllability of the oxide portion width on the gate sidewall, prevents etching away of the source/drain region, and avoids leakage currents due to hot-carrier injection.
* The invention includes using a high melting point metal or silicide for the oxide portion, forming the LDD structure in a low temperature process, and preventing degradation of transconductance and increased resistances.

* The present invention relates to an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication, addressing the limitations of current IP telephones.
* It proposes an enhanced radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as an improved IP telephone, offering convenience, economy, and efficiency.
* The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder for low power consumption, allowing effective IP telephony with a low-performance PC.
* It connects via a cable to a PC's serial or parallel port, facilitating bidirectional digital speech and control signaling.
* The system supports manual or automatic switching between ordinary wireless and IP-telephone operation, enabling initiation of calls from either the PC or the enhanced radio telephone.
* The invention provides a low-cost IP telephone solution, reducing speech delay and echo problems, suitable for various network interfaces including PSTN, wireless, and data networks.

* The invention relates to devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water, or other useful work from surface waves on a water body.
* The devices rely on overhead wave-induced subsurface differences in hydrostatic pressure and/or enhanced surge or pitch to expand and contract or otherwise deform or deflect one or more gas-filled submerged containers, producing useful work.
* The energy capture is enhanced or supplemented by wave focusing, reflection, or diffraction techniques and/or by overhead surface floating bodies.
* The devices are designed to be deployed at depths slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs, with the depth adjustable for tides and optimized for energy capture.
* The devices use a flexible, gas-tight, reinforced, elastomer or flexible metal bellows or diaphragm to connect fixed and movable container ends, allowing for enhanced energy capture through partial evacuation or venting.

• The invention pertains to a scraped surface heat exchanger blade for mounting onto a drive shaft, addressing the need for an efficient and secure installation process.

• Blades are typically rectangular, thin flat members with a scraping edge and a hinge side hingedly connected to the drive shaft via pins.

• Blades are installed at an angle to prevent lateral movement during insertion, requiring manual or string assistance in vertically arranged exchangers.

• Blades are usually arranged in groups of four, each at a 90° angle around the circumference of the drive shaft, for optimal mixing and scraping.

• In vertically oriented exchangers, blades can fall freely if not properly restrained, necessitating a method to facilitate their mounting without compromising safety or efficiency.

• The present invention introduces a blade design with L-shaped locking tracks on both sides, enhancing the pin connection's stability and preventing lateral movement during installation.

• These tracks, one on each side of the blade, allow for secure mounting while ensuring the blade remains aligned with the pin, even when rotated to an installation angle.

• The tracks are dimensioned to permit sliding along the pins but prevent out-of-track movements, ensuring the blade stays securely in place during the installation process.

• The blade's design ensures that only the correct side faces up, aligning the scraper edge correctly against the inner tube of the heat exchanger, thus optimizing performance.

• The tracks on both sides of the blade reduce the amount of thinned track area compared to a single-sided track design, extending the blade's lifespan and maintaining structural integrity.

• The method for mounting the blade to the drive shaft, utilizing these innovative tracks, facilitates a more streamlined and safer installation process, particularly in vertically oriented scraped surface heat exchangers.

* The invention addresses the issue of disruptions caused by transversely located or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a production machine.
* A detection process uses an optical checking element, like a camera, to scan images of cigarettes, evaluates them, and produces an error signal for deviations from reference images or values.
* A detection apparatus includes a camera, image-processing device, and error signal production mechanism for monitoring the cigarette magazine.
* The process and apparatus enable monitoring a large area of cigarettes, detecting orientation deviations, and registering defective cigarettes.
* Errors can be eliminated manually or automatically, with manual intervention signaled acoustically or optically.
* An elimination process acts on detected defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes by ejecting them from the magazine.
* An elimination apparatus features ejecting units arranged in the magazine, capable of removing cigarettes in a large enough quantity to clear transversely located ones.
* Ejecting units are designed with different front and rear wall sizes to prevent partial gripping and jamming of cigarettes.
* The system includes multiple ejecting zones and units, allowing for efficient clearance of disruptions without ejecting the entire magazine's contents.

* The present invention provides a simplified connection system for high voltage cables, applicable to various accessories and interconnections, aiming for factory pretesting, reduced installation time and cost, and simplified field testing.
* The interface components do not include gas or oil, ensuring no leakage or explosion, and the stress cone design and dimensions are consistent across applications, with only the cable or apparatus entrance diameter varying.
* The outer cone concept is highlighted, offering advantages over the inner cone concept, such as separating the cable connection further from the apparatus, reducing the likelihood of one side affecting the other in case of faults.
* The invention is demonstrated through various applications, including SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, outdoor terminals, straight through joints, transition joints, and joints between two apparatus, showcasing its versatility and benefits.

* The invention presents an improved fixing mechanism for a tool, addressing the limitations of the conic fit by employing curved surfaces for tool fixation. This mechanism simplifies and secures the tool placement process, allowing for efficient transmission of machining forces between the tool, frame, and holder.
* The mechanism utilizes a curved surface in the tool frame and holder, designed to ensure a secure connection with a specific formula relating the radius of curvature, contact surface diameter, and distance between the center of curvature and the contact surface. This design facilitates a simple, compatible, and robust fixing mechanism, enhancing tool exchange and operation in various applications, particularly in sheet machining centers.

* The invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits with high efficiency and low EMI output, utilizing modified switching regulator circuits with multiple current paths that cancel out radiated noise and additional terminal lines to sink any generated EMI.
* The provided circuits enable the production of sufficient current to drive large displays, such as those in Apple's iPhone and iPod Touch products, without the typical penalties associated with EMI or noise, by alternating source and drain paths and using terminal leads to reduce EMI.

* The text discusses a method for optimizing the charging of vehicle batteries to reduce the time spent on balancing and charging. It introduces algorithms that adjust the charging rate for different cells to achieve equal voltages more efficiently.
* Key aspects include determining the maximum capacity of each cell, calculating the common voltage needed for a target drive range, and using resistive circuitry activation times to balance cells during charging. The algorithms aim to minimize the overall charging time by intelligently managing the charging process.

• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter designed as a lamp power supply, converting AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage at a predetermined value set by a potentiometer, ensuring no low or high frequency flicker and no electromagnetic radiation for reduced eye fatigue and health protection.

• The converter includes components such as input power supply, protection circuits, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, and control circuit, with the ability to adjust brightness through a potentiometer and maintain stable output voltage through feedback and dimming circuits.

• The power supply can be implemented using various topologies like Buck, Boost, Buck-boost, and Flyback, with the control circuit utilizing IC controllers or discrete components to convert the rectified sinusoidal voltage to constant DC voltage, ensuring no low or high frequency components and no electromagnetic radiation for optimal eye health and minimal fatigue.

• The invention provides a new approach to maintaining illumination in a space using both daylight and electric lights, with variable and flexible daylight compensation.

• It allows for integrated control of window treatments using a single photosensor or averaged sensor readings for both electric light control and window treatment adjustment.

• The system can maintain multiple lighting profiles, each with different requirements for overall illumination and spatial distribution.

• Two control options are described: "open loop" for electric light control based on interior light sensors, and "closed loop" for electric light control that combines interior and exterior light sources.

• A closed loop system for window shading control is implemented based on the light readings from a sensor sensing daylight entering the space.

• The system uses a single signal from a single light sensor or group of sensors for both window treatment control and electric light level adjustment.

• It eliminates the need for exterior sensors and complex data gathering, reducing overall system cost.

• The system can automatically control and reduce sun glare, without significantly sacrificing energy savings from daylight use.

• It maximizes daylight savings by closing window treatments only during glare incidents and when sunlight exceeds a preset calibration value.

• The system adjusts window treatments based on available daylight, aiming to prevent glare, and stops when the desired illumination profile is achieved within a predefined tolerance.

* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was established post-9/11 to ensure security in all modes of transportation, with a primary focus on aviation.
* Before 9/11, significant vulnerabilities in aviation security existed, including weak screening of passengers and baggage, inadequate access controls, and unprotected air traffic control systems.
* TSA has made substantial progress in implementing aviation security measures, such as deploying federal screeners, using explosives detection systems, and hardening cockpit doors.
* However, challenges remain, including securing air cargo, improving general aviation security, and addressing airport perimeter vulnerabilities.
* TSA faces long-term challenges in managing funding, coordinating efforts, ensuring strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization.
* A risk management approach is being adopted to prioritize resources and efforts based on security needs and asset criticality.
* Funding issues, particularly for installing and integrating explosives detection systems, and accountability concerns over reprogramming funds are critical.
* TSA's efforts to strengthen aviation security are ongoing, with a focus on leveraging technology, improving efficiency, and maintaining a balance between security and customer service.

* The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) were enacted at different times for distinct purposes. LDA aims to increase public disclosure of lobbying efforts, while IRC sections focus on tax implications.
* LDA requires organizations to register and semiannually report lobbying expenditures and other information related to federal officials' influence. IRC sections cover lobbying of federal, state, and local officials, with different emphases.
* Organizations lobbying on their own behalf can choose to use the LDA, IRC section 4911, or IRC section 162(e) definition for calculating expenses. This choice can significantly affect registration and reporting requirements.
* The LDA definition covers lobbying of all federal officials for any subject, while IRC sections cover lobbying of federal officials for legislative matters and state/local officials for legislative matters only.
* Organizations using the IRC definitions might not register under LDA if their expenses fall below the $20,500 threshold, or might report less information relevant to LDA's purpose.
* Options to address discrepancies include harmonizing definitions, eliminating IRC definitions for LDA purposes, or requiring use of only federal lobbying expenses under IRC definitions for LDA.
* Harmonizing definitions could better align LDA's purpose but would require revisiting fundamental decisions about lobbying definitions. Eliminating IRC definitions could simplify reporting but might increase burden for some organizations.
* Options to improve LDA's public disclosure purpose exist, but Congress must weigh benefits against potential additional reporting burdens.

• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has assessed strategic sourcing and its potential value in federal acquisitions for over a decade, highlighting its importance in achieving substantial savings through structural changes and leveraging buying power.

• Strategic sourcing encompasses various tactics for more efficient and effective procurement, including leveraged buying, demand management, standardization, total cost of ownership evaluation, and supplier relationship management.

• The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) implemented strategic sourcing practices in 2005, directing agencies to conduct spend analyses and develop strategic sourcing efforts. The Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI) was established to address government-wide opportunities for strategic sourcing and eliminate duplication across agencies.

• Despite OMB's efforts, agencies have only leveraged a fraction of their buying power through strategic sourcing, with the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Energy, and Department of Veterans Affairs accounting for 80% of federal procurement spending but managing only 5% through strategic sourcing in fiscal year 2011.

* The current surface transportation programs in the U.S. are ineffective in addressing national transportation challenges due to a lack of clear vision, performance links, and best tools for investment decisions.
* The federal role in surface transportation has expanded over time, incorporating various goals, programs, and grant structures, but this has led to unclear goals, indirect links to needs, and insufficient performance mechanisms.
* Many federal surface transportation programs lack the best tools and approaches, such as economic analysis for project selection, and do not ensure fiscal sustainability, with the Highway Trust Fund facing a funding imbalance.
* The principles for restructuring surface transportation programs include defining national interests, establishing clear federal roles, incorporating performance measures, employing effective tools, and ensuring financial stability.
* Various funding and financing options, including taxes, user fees, and public-private partnerships, are available to address projected funding shortfalls, with considerations for affordability, equity, and national interests.

• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) faces concerns about its funding structure, including revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency. Stakeholders support the current excise tax system, noting its simplicity and low administrative costs, while FAA and some stakeholders argue that the disconnect between revenues and costs raises concerns.

• Alternative funding options, such as relying solely on a fuel tax or increasing the passenger segment tax, could potentially address revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency concerns. However, each option has limitations, and a combination of options might offer the most promise for aligning revenues and costs.

* The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 discussing secret U.S. chemical weapons programs during World War II, estimating 60,000 military personnel participated in human experimental tests.
* In 1993, GAO issued a report finding VA lacked information on individuals exposed to mustard agents and lewisite during DOD chemical tests.
* In response to congressional inquiries, DOD established a task force to identify personnel exposed to chemical substances, resulting in the identification of approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians.
* The Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (OUSD) (P&R) created a database and sent commendation certificates to over 700 individuals.
* DOD, VA, and Congress exchanged correspondence on the need to identify individuals exposed during Project 112 tests, leading to the Defense Authorization Act for FY 2003.
* The act required DOD to submit a comprehensive plan for reviewing and declassifying records related to Project 112, identifying 5,842 servicemembers and 350 civilians potentially exposed.
* DOD stopped actively searching for additional individuals in 2003, but additional exposures were identified through non-DOD sources, including the Institute of Medicine's study.
* DOD's current effort to identify individuals exposed outside of Project 112 lacks clear objectives, scope, and information needs, and has management and oversight weaknesses.
* DOD has not included civilians in its current effort, has not worked with veterans or veterans service organizations, and has not kept Congress and the public fully informed.
* DOD and VA have had limited success in notifying individuals potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances, with inconsistent information transmission and challenges in obtaining contact information.
* DOD has not taken actions to notify civilians potentially exposed, and there is no specific guidance on civilian notification.
* GAO recommends DOD conduct a cost-benefit analysis, coordinate with VA and veterans organizations, and notify civilians potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances.

* The government of Mexico has sought to combat the growing power of criminal groups since the 1980s and 1990s.
* In 2006, President Felipe Calderón mobilized military and law enforcement agencies to disrupt DTO operations and target leadership structures.
* Under President Enrique Peña Nieto, emphasis shifted to reducing criminal violence threatening civilians and the business sector.
* DTOs' criminal activities now extend beyond trafficking narcotics to include human trafficking, kidnapping, money laundering, extortion, and more.
* Firearms are crucial for DTOs to assert control, eliminate rivals, enforce business dealings, and resist government operations.
* The majority of firearms seized in Mexico and traced back to the US originated from Texas, California, and Arizona.
* ATF and ICE have taken steps to improve coordination, including updating a 2009 MOU, but persistent challenges in information sharing and jurisdictional disagreements remain.
* The National Southwest Border Counternarcotics Strategy lacks an adequate indicator to measure progress in stemming firearms trafficking to Mexico.

* NCHIP, managed by BJS, aims to build a national infrastructure for exchanging criminal history records, enhancing their accuracy, completeness, and accessibility.
* States use NCHIP funds to automate records, with a focus on NICS-related purposes, including improving records related to federal firearms disqualifiers and enhancing access through III.
* States have made progress in automating criminal history records, with the percentage of automated records increasing from 79% in 1993 to 89% by 2001.
* NCHIP encourages states to improve disposition reporting, which is critical for determining whether individuals are legally prohibited from purchasing firearms.
* Automated information on the disposition of felony and other potentially disqualifying arrests is not always widely available, affecting NICS background checks.
* NCHIP has provided over $438 million in grants to states, with states investing significantly more in system improvements, often beyond the required 10% match.
* NCHIP is viewed as an umbrella program that coordinates various funding streams for criminal history record improvements.
* Limited progress has been made in automating records for nonfelony or noncriminal categories that prohibit firearm purchases, such as domestic violence misdemeanors and mental health commitments.
* BJS is developing a criminal history records quality index (RQI) to assess and monitor performance across jurisdictions, aiming to improve the system's quality and accessibility.
* Factors for policymakers considering the future of NCHIP include the demand for background checks, technological advancements, and the need for sustained funding to address ongoing challenges.

• EPA created the Superfund program in 1980 to address the nation's most severely contaminated hazardous waste sites, with incineration being used as a cleanup remedy in about 6% of decisions through fiscal year 1995. 

• Three active incinerators were operating at Superfund sites at the time of the review: the Bayou Bonfouca site in Louisiana, the Times Beach site in Missouri, and the Baird and McGuire site in Massachusetts. Each site had specific safety measures and oversight to ensure the incinerators operated safely.

• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were found to be fairly presented in all material respects, according to U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.  
• However, the SEC faced a material weakness in its financial reporting process, along with significant deficiencies in internal controls, which may lead to misstatements in financial information.  
• The material weakness was identified in the period-end financial reporting process, accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties, transaction fee revenue accounting, and financial statement disclosures preparation.  
• Significant deficiencies were noted in information security, property and equipment controls, and accounting for budgetary resources.  
• The SEC's financial management system did not fully comply with OMB Circular No. A-127 requirements, affecting the integration and efficiency of its financial systems.  
• Errors in calculating accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties, and in accounting for transaction fees, were found, increasing the risk of significant misstatements.  
• The SEC's financial reporting process was found to be complex and prone to errors due to manual processes and lack of integration between systems.

* The U.S. Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with the EAS workforce consisting primarily of employees in positions 11 through 26.
* The EAS workforce, which includes management-level positions, totaled 80,238, or about 10% of total Service career-level employees.
* The Postal Service created its Diversity Development Department in 1992 to foster an inclusive business environment and actively support the recruitment, retention, and upward mobility of women and minorities.
* The Postal Service Board of Governors commissioned Aguirre International to study workforce diversity in 1997, which found that women and minorities appeared to experience problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions.
* The Postal Service developed an action plan in response to the Aguirre report, focusing on promoting diversity and improving recruitment, hiring, and promotion activities.
* The Postal Service collects a variety of diversity-related data and has initiatives under way to improve data collection methods and use, but lacks reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes.

• DOD defines Military Working Dogs (MWDs) as canines bred, procured, or acquired to support military operations, including explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, tracking, and other requirements. MWDs are removed from service due to medical or behavioral issues, when no longer needed, or in other circumstances.

• Robby's Law, enacted in 2000, promotes the adoption of MWDs after their military service, requiring the military to make suitable dogs available for adoption at the end of their "useful life" or when no longer needed. The law has been amended, prioritizing former handlers for adoption, followed by others capable of humane care, and lastly, law enforcement agencies.

* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet, aiming for a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of armed reconnaissance and attack.
* The program faced significant challenges, including increased costs, delays, and technical issues with software development and aircraft maintainability.
* The Secretary of Defense directed restructuring in 1994 due to budgetary constraints, extending development by 3 years, reducing funding, and deferring production decisions.
* The Army proposed acquiring six "early operational capability" aircraft in addition to two prototypes, aiming to better evaluate the aircraft's mission capability before committing to production.
* The restructured program continues risks associated with concurrent production and testing, potentially leading to higher costs and reduced performance, especially concerning software development and maintainability goals.

• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits for food purchases.
• FNS funds food stamp benefits and half of states' administrative costs, setting rules for program implementation.
• States determine household eligibility, calculate monthly benefits, and issue benefits based on income and asset limits.
• TANF recipients are automatically eligible for food stamps, and states can extend eligibility to those receiving TANF-funded services.
• FNS offers options and waivers to simplify food stamp rules, reduce reporting burden, and increase program access.

* HUD, established in 1965, oversees housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
* It employs 9,386 staff and operates through annual appropriations subject to spending limits.
* HUD provides housing assistance through public and private-market programs, with budgetary constraints limiting eligibility.
* Community development funds are distributed through grants to states, cities, towns, and counties for economic development.
* The Federal Housing Administration insures mortgages for single-family and multifamily properties, and the Government National Mortgage Association guarantees loan securities.
* HUD regulates areas like land sales, home mortgage services, manufactured housing, and enforces fair housing laws.
* The fiscal year 2000 budget proposal includes a 9% increase in budget authority, with new initiatives and programs.
* HUD's Section 8 housing assistance program faces issues with budget accuracy and unexpended balances.
* The CDBG program provides grants for community development, with set-asides for specific purposes.
* IDIS, HUD's information system, lacks detailed performance information and is not secure.
* The Contract Administration initiative aims to relieve HUD staff of duties, but raises concerns about oversight.

• DOD developed facility requirements for the replacement medical center, considering beneficiary population data, contingency operations, and troop strength. 
• The center was designed for peacetime operations but with capacity to expand for contingency operations. 
• DOD used beneficiary population data and historical patterns to define catchment areas, with the majority of beneficiaries within a 55-mile radius. 
• The center is sized for peacetime operations, with flexibility to expand during surges, and is designed to handle casualties similar to those in Fallujah, Iraq. 
• DOD has been reducing its military posture in Europe, affecting the beneficiary population and potentially impacting the facility's requirements.

* The report examines how Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) ensures fair, reasoned, and efficient use of discretion in alien apprehension and removal decisions.
* ICE has designed internal controls, including training, guidance, and monitoring, to guide and oversee officers' decision-making processes, aligning with federal government internal control standards.
* To address the exercise of discretion, ICE plans to update existing policies by 2008, develop a mechanism for consistent legal guidance dissemination, and evaluate the costs and alternatives for collecting data on officer decision-making trends.

* The report examines the costs and revenues of ground ambulance services provided by various organizations, which differ in structure, staffing, transport types, and funding sources.
* Medicare payments for these services consist of a service-level payment for the type of transport and a mileage payment, with providers potentially affiliated with institutions or operating independently.
* Providers can be for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based, using volunteers, paid staff, or both, and offer nonemergency or emergency transports, with some providing basic or advanced life support.
* Revenue sources vary by community support, charitable donations, state and federal grants, subscription programs, and insurance payments, with costs per transport influenced by factors like volume, Medicare mix, and government subsidies.

• The Department of Defense's (DOD) Supply Chain Integration office is responsible for leading the development of DOD supply chain policies and improving accountability, visibility, and control of critical assets, including SRC I ammunition.

• The Army plays a prominent role in managing SRC I ammunition, procuring a majority of the department's ammunition and providing wholesale storage for other military services at Army depots.

• DOD has designated the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command, under USTRANSCOM, as the single manager for transportation of SRC I ammunition, including coordinating responses to transportation issues while in transit.

• DOD policy requires continuous program and policy oversight to ensure protection of sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explosives, including SRC I ammunition, within DOD.

• The military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, which also maintain item-specific data such as serial number, production lot number, and quantity.

• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest single producer, collector, and user of information in the United States, responsible for issuing Social Security numbers and maintaining records for various federal programs.

• SSA's disclosure policy for law enforcement is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and most federal agencies, aiming to protect individuals' privacy while complying with applicable statutes.

• SSA's policy requires officials to consider factors such as the nature of the alleged criminal activity, the information requested, and the agency making the request before sharing personal information.

• The policy allows SSA to share information under certain conditions, including fraud in Social Security programs, nonviolent crimes in similar government programs, violent crimes, and provisions of other federal statutes requiring disclosure.

• SSA's Office of Inspector General (OIG) is authorized to disclose individuals' personal information to law enforcement agencies under a memorandum of understanding with SSA, subject to the same requirements as outlined in SSA's policy.

• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than those of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Bureau of the Census, which have disclosure requirements prescribed in their statutes.

• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) aims to minimize threats to human health and the environment from hazardous waste management. 

• RCRA governs hazardous waste from generation to final disposal, focusing on preventing contamination. 

• The law identifies and lists hazardous waste based on specific criteria, including industrial processes and characteristics like flammability. 

• RCRA's requirements apply to all hazardous waste, regardless of origin, including waste from cleanups, and regulate environmental media mixed with hazardous waste. 

• Several legislative proposals have aimed to exempt certain remediation waste from RCRA requirements, giving states more authority to manage it. 

• EPA has identified RCRA remediation waste as a key area for statutory reform due to high implementation costs compared to environmental benefits. 

• Cleanup managers often cite land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements as creating disincentives for cleanups. 

• Land disposal restrictions and associated treatment standards are costly and complex, often requiring stringent treatment that may not be necessary for low-risk materials. 

• Minimum technological requirements for facilities treating or disposing of hazardous waste can be more stringent than necessary for remediation waste. 

• Permitting processes can significantly increase cleanup costs and cause delays, especially for facilities not in the hazardous waste business. 

• Leaving remediation waste in place, rather than managing or treating it, is sometimes chosen to avoid RCRA requirements, potentially compromising long-term protection.

* The Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) was established in 1996 to support program integrity activities.
* MIP funding ranges from $430 million to $440 million annually, increasing to $720 million in 2003 and remaining at that amount since.
* CMS allocates MIP funds primarily to support contractors' program integrity efforts for traditional Medicare, including fiscal intermediaries, carriers, PSCs, and MACs.
* Contractors use MIP funds for activities like audits, medical reviews, secondary payer operations, benefit integrity, and provider education.
* Provider education received the largest percentage increase in funding, growing by 590% from 1997 to 2005.
* Expenditures for medical review increased 40% from 1997 to 2005, while spending on secondary payer and benefit integrity increased by 49% and 89%, respectively.
* CMS has not consistently used quantitative data or qualitative information to assess the effectiveness of MIP activities.
* CMS plans to use some of the additional $112 million provided by DRA for fiscal year 2006 to support Part D program integrity efforts.
* Medicare contracting reform, requiring all claims administration work to be transferred to MACs by 2011, will affect future MIP funding allocations.
* CMS intends to increase the use of MIP funds for award payments to contractors to encourage superior performance.
* CMS has developed two initiatives to provide objective measures of the results of audit and provider education activities.

• TSA has taken several actions to enhance screener training, including updating the training curriculum, implementing a dual-function basic training program, and providing online learning options.

• Challenges remain in providing recurrent training, with some airports facing staffing shortages and connectivity issues that limit access to online training resources.

• TSA has enhanced its basic screener training program by updating the curriculum and deploying a new dual-function basic training course.

• Despite progress, some Federal Security Directors (FSDs) identified a need for additional training in specific areas such as leadership, communication, and supervision.

• FSDs reported difficulties in providing recurrent training due to insufficient staffing and connectivity issues at some training facilities.

• TSA has implemented leadership and technical training programs for screening supervisors, but additional training is needed based on FSD feedback.

• TSA has faced challenges in providing access to online training, particularly at airports without high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity.

• Without a clear plan for prioritizing and scheduling high-speed connectivity deployment, TSA's ability to provide online training is unclear.

• TSA has improved its efforts to measure and enhance screener performance, including increasing covert testing and deploying the Threat Image Projection (TIP) system.

• However, performance measurement efforts have primarily focused on passenger screening, and checked baggage screening performance data are limited.

• TSA has established performance measures and indexes for both passenger and checked baggage screening systems but has not yet established performance targets for all components.

• Establishing performance targets for individual index components would enable TSA to focus its improvement efforts more effectively.

* The IRS faces an annual challenge in determining the staffing level for its toll-free telephone customer service operations.
* IRS does not have a long-term, desired level-of-service goal based on taxpayers' needs and cost-benefit analysis.
* It instead sets annual goals based on funding and balancing service and compliance activities within budget constraints.
* IRS has not established a strategic plan with multi-year goals for its customer service workforce.
* Other organizations determine staffing requirements based on customer needs and have clear service-level goals.
* IRS is considering adopting measures used by other organizations and establishing goals for those measures.
* Call sites face challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives.
* Recruiters struggle with job characteristics such as seasonal nature, undesirable hours, and stress.
* Training is affected by resource constraints, outdated materials, and the cyclical nature of taxpayer demand.
* Refresher training is not provided despite the need for continuous learning and adaptation.
* IRS does not actively monitor attrition, reasons for leaving, or whether representatives move within or outside the organization.
* Scheduling staff is complicated due to inaccurate forecasting and a complex process.
* IRS is adapting an automated system to improve forecasting and scheduling, but data collection and system capability are issues.
* Evaluations of human capital management practices do not assess their impact on achieving service goals or interrelationships among practices.
* IRS needs to establish a long-term service-level goal, assess refresher training needs, monitor attrition, and consider the effects of practices on service goals.
* The Commissioner of Internal Revenue agreed with the recommendations and highlighted ongoing efforts to improve human capital management practices.
* IRS is developing competency-based recruiting and retention methods and plans to establish a system for assessing individual refresher training needs.
* The Commissioner's comments did not fully address the recommendation to consider the effects of practices on achieving customer service goals.
* Comparisons of IRS' performance before and after operational changes are appropriate for evaluating the impact of new initiatives.
* IRS' reported tax law accuracy in 1998 and 1999 was removed from the report due to changes in measurement methods.

• Ginnie Mae, a unit of HUD, operates as a secondary market for federally insured and guaranteed housing loans, providing a secondary market outlet for loans from FHA, VA, RHS, and PIH programs.

• Ginnie Mae's market share of new MBS issuance has declined from 42% in 1985 to 7% in 2004, primarily due to rapid growth in the conventional MBS market.

• Ginnie Mae's share of the overall MBS market has also declined, falling from 54% in 1985 to 10% in 2004, mainly because of increased securitization of conventional mortgages.

• Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has declined, falling from $612 billion in 2000 to $453 billion in 2004, mainly due to borrowers refinancing out of FHA and VA programs into conventional loans.

• Ginnie Mae's market share decline is not expected to significantly impact interest rates or credit availability for borrowers, as other secondary market players would need to offer competitive products.

• Ginnie Mae faces challenges in maintaining its market share, including responding to changes in the marketplace, ensuring adequate disclosure of loan information, managing commitment authority, and improving data systems and internal controls.

• Ginnie Mae has taken steps to address these challenges, such as expanding product offerings, improving disclosures, and enhancing its commitment authority process.

• Ginnie Mae's revenue exceeds its expenses, contributing to a reduction in the federal budget deficit, and its program income is likely to continue exceeding expenses in the foreseeable future.

• Ginnie Mae's small staff and reliance on contractors require it to ensure that its capacity to plan, manage, and oversee contractors is adequate to meet its mission and challenges.

• The General Accounting Office (GAO) reviewed Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS) actions to correct $615 million in illegal and improper closed account adjustments from fiscal year 2000. DFAS agreed that $592 million of these adjustments should not have been made and reversed them.

• For the remaining $23 million, DFAS provided documentation showing $8 million were proper, while GAO still considers the remaining $15 million unnecessary or unsupported adjustments.

• Reversing the $592 million in adjustments identified additional accounting errors on 30 contracts, totaling $457 million (77% of the reversed transactions). Correcting these errors is estimated to take over 21,000 hours.

• DFAS reversed $172 million of illegal or improper closed account adjustments made in fiscal year 2001, agreeing to correct the remaining $119 million. DOD plans to review another $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 adjustments by December 2002.

• DOD's reported closed account adjustments dropped by about 80% in the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002, from over $1 billion in fiscal year 2001, attributed to increased management and employee emphasis on resolving issues.

• The Internet's domain name system relies on a set of functions to ensure the uniqueness of e-mail and web site addresses, with the domain name system's rules determining which top-level domains are recognized.

• The U.S. government initially supported the implementation of the domain name system, transitioning technical responsibility to the private sector in 1998 through a Department of Commerce policy statement, or "White Paper," emphasizing stability, competition, representation, and private coordination.

• The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) was established to manage the domain name system, with the Department of Commerce entering into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to guide the transition.

• ICANN has made progress in promoting competition by allowing other companies to register domain names, expanding the pool of available domain names, and enhancing the stability and security of the root servers.

• However, progress on formalizing relationships with root server and country-code domain operators, improving security and stability, and ensuring representation of the Internet community has been slow.

• The White Paper's guiding principles for the transition have not been fully implemented, particularly regarding the creation of a representative board and the development of mechanisms for global and functional diversity representation.

• The Department of Commerce has limited oversight of ICANN, focusing on ensuring the corporation has the resources and capability to manage the domain name system, but has not issued status reports or publicly commented on ICANN's reform proposals.

* The Department of the Interior (Interior) has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820, with reforms initiated in 1994 to improve trust management.
* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) was established to oversee these reforms, with a Comprehensive Trust Management Plan issued in 2003.
* OST has implemented several key reforms, including the Trust Funds Accounting System (TFAS) and the Trust Beneficiary Call Center, to improve trust fund management.
* The agency has also reorganized, increasing staff and budget to support trust reform efforts, with a focus on trust records management and land appraisals.
* Despite progress, OST has not provided a timetable for completing remaining reforms or identified a termination date, as required by the 1994 Act.
* The agency has relied heavily on contractors for trust reform activities, spending nearly 21% of its funds on contracts in fiscal years 2004 and 2005.
* The use of contractors has raised concerns about preferential treatment, leading to ethics training for OST employees and a review of the contracts.
* OST has not developed a workforce plan to reassess staffing needs once reforms are completed, potentially missing opportunities for realignment or cost reduction.
* The Special Trustee plans to reduce expenditures by terminating contracts as reforms are completed, but the size of the current staff is considered appropriate for future operations.
* The report recommends that Interior provide a timetable for completing reforms, a plan for future trust fund operations, and develop a workforce plan to reassess staffing needs.

• The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the Department of Defense (DOD) initiated joint efforts in 1998 to develop a comprehensive, lifelong medical record for service members, aiming to share patient health information between VA and DOD facilities. Their first project, the Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR), faced challenges due to a lack of clear leadership, mission, and planning, leading to recommendations for improvement in 2001 and 2002.

• In response to these recommendations, VA and DOD renamed the project to the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program, designated VA as the lead entity, and completed the first phase in July 2002, enabling the transfer of data from DOD's health information system to a VA-accessible database. The second phase was finalized in March 2004, enhancing VA's capability to share health information with DOD.

• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) outlines the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability for the audited entity. 
• IRS employs nine audit standards to ensure audit quality, covering areas like scope, techniques, technical conclusions, and time management. 
• Audit workpapers serve as documentation for the audit process, aiding in planning, recording procedures, supporting technical conclusions, and providing basis for management review. 
• The Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) evaluates audit quality, with the workpaper standard focusing on documentation of audit trail, techniques, and conclusions. 
• IRS requires workpapers to fully disclose audit methods, be clear and organized, agree with tax adjustments, document activity records, and protect taxpayer privacy. 
• Issues found in audit workpapers include discrepancies in tax adjustments, missing required documents, and inadequate legibility or completeness. 
• Supervisory review during audits is crucial for quality control, but documentation of these reviews is limited, with only about 6% of workpapers showing such review. 
• IRS officials note that all unagreed audits are reviewed by group managers, but documentation of these reviews is not always included in workpapers. 
• Proposed changes to the IRM aim to require documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process. 
• The lack of documentation on supervisory review raises questions about the extent of managerial oversight and the quality of workpapers. 
• GAO recommends that IRS require audit supervisors to document their review of workpapers to ensure quality control. 
• IRS agreed to implement this recommendation by revising the IRM instructions by October 1998. 
• IRS expressed concerns about the draft report's portrayal of managerial practices and the sufficiency of these practices. 
• Documentation of supervisory review is essential for ensuring quality control over workpapers and audits. 
• The report's findings highlight the importance of supervisory review in maintaining audit quality and minimizing taxpayer burden. 
• IRS's response to the recommendation indicates a commitment to improving documentation practices in the audit process. 
• The proposed changes to the IRM aim to address the issue of documentation of managerial involvement in audits. 
• The lack of documentation on supervisory review raises questions about the effectiveness of current oversight mechanisms. 
• GAO's recommendation emphasizes the need for clear documentation of supervisory review to enhance audit quality and transparency.

* The U.S. State Department's Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program was authorized in 1983 to enhance friendly countries' antiterrorism skills and strengthen bilateral ties.
* ATA offers a wide range of counterterrorism assistance, primarily through training courses and grants of equipment like small arms, bomb detection tools, vehicles, and computers.
* The program's funding has fluctuated, increasing to $158 million in 2002 and reaching almost $171 million in 2007.
* The Coordinator for Counterterrorism oversees the program, while the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security implements security programs.
* The ATA program's effectiveness is limited by a lack of systematic guidance from the State Department's Counterterrorism Bureau and unclear assessment processes.
* The program's needs assessments and reviews lack prioritization and timeframes, hindering resource allocation decisions.
* The program lacks clear measures for assessing sustainability, making it difficult to determine the long-term impact of assistance.
* The State Department has not complied with a congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance since 1996.
* The annual reports on the ATA program contain inaccuracies and lack systematic assessments of program performance.
* The program's effectiveness is limited by these issues, making it challenging to determine the most effective types of assistance for partner nations.

* The U.S. Bankruptcy Code provides two approaches for reorganizing or terminating large financial companies: judicial bankruptcy process and special legal and regulatory resolution regimes.
* Bankruptcy aims to help individuals and businesses eliminate or restructure debts and ensures equitable treatment of creditors.
* Financial companies can seek liquidation under Chapter 7 or reorganization under Chapter 11, which can be voluntary or initiated by creditors.
* Involuntary bankruptcy proceedings allow debtors to defend against the proceeding, and the judge decides whether to permit the bankruptcy to proceed.
* A Chapter 7 proceeding involves a trustee overseeing the liquidation of assets, while a Chapter 11 proceeding allows debtors to continue operations under court supervision.
* A firm going through a Chapter 11 bankruptcy typically passes through stages including first-day motions, disclosure, plan of reorganization, and reorganization outcomes.
* The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, and the Department of Justice's U.S. Trustee Program.
* A preference action can be asserted for payments made to insiders within a year prior to bankruptcy filing, and large financial companies generally file under Chapter 11.
* Regulators often play a role in financial company bankruptcies, and the Federal Reserve and FDIC oversee bankruptcy trustees to ensure integrity and efficiency.
* The Code includes "safe harbor provisions" for qualified financial contracts (QFCs), allowing counterparties to exercise certain contractual rights during bankruptcy.
* The Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) gives FDIC the authority to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy, focusing on the parent holding company level.
* Challenges in resolving failed financial companies across national frameworks include varying insolvency laws, legal authorities, and regulatory regimes across countries.
* Chapter 15 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code facilitates coordination between U.S. and foreign parties in cross-border insolvency cases, excluding certain financial institutions.
* Two bills were introduced in the 113th Congress to address challenges in reorganizing large financial firms under Chapter 11, but neither was signed into law.
* The Taxpayer Protection and Responsible Resolution Act and the Financial Institution Bankruptcy Act proposed changes to the role of regulators, treatment of QFCs, and designation of judges.
* The 21st Century Glass-Steagall Act of 2013 aimed to repeal all safe harbor provisions for QFCs, but it was not signed into law.

* The electricity industry comprises generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* Smart grid modernization involves integrating new technologies and IT systems to enhance reliability, efficiency, and consumer information.
* Federal and state governments oversee the industry, with FERC regulating wholesale electricity sales and transmission, and state commissions handling local distribution.
* Cybersecurity threats to the electricity grid are evolving, originating from both unintentional and intentional sources, including advanced persistent threats.
* NIST, FERC, and other entities have taken steps to develop and enforce cybersecurity standards and guidelines for smart grid systems.
* Challenges in securing the electricity grid include monitoring implementation, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, adopting a comprehensive approach, ensuring built-in security, effectively sharing information, and establishing metrics for evaluating cybersecurity.
