• The team discussed the project's evaluation, focusing on the prototype's design, functionality, and cost. They aimed to create a remote control that was both fashionable and technologically innovative, inspired by current fashion trends.

• Despite the budget constraints, the team managed to create a prototype with an L_C_D_ display, a joystick, and a single curved design. However, they had to compromise on additional features like a locator, multiple languages, and a U_S_B_ connection due to cost issues.

• The evaluation of the prototype revealed that it scored well in terms of ease of use, design, and technology, but was rated lower in cost-effectiveness and fashion inspiration. The team decided to keep the L_C_D_ display and focus on a plastic, single curved case to reduce costs.

• The team suggested conducting market research to test the product's sales potential with different designs, aiming to find a balance between cost and consumer appeal. They also discussed the possibility of selling the product directly to manufacturers, recognizing a significant market opportunity.

• The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015's objectives, including regulation, safeguarding public good, maintaining fair access, and protecting institutional autonomy, have been subject to scrutiny. The Minister for Education acknowledges the need to adapt the legislation to align with current circumstances and future goals.
• The Act's powers of intervention, particularly the lack of flexibility and perceived inflexibility, have been discussed. The Minister intends to ensure the new commission has a range of flexible regulatory tools, including the ability to offer advice, guidance, and enhanced monitoring, to address issues more effectively.
• The fee and access plans' effectiveness is questioned, with a preference for longer-term, outcome-focused agreements over annual plans. The Minister plans to incorporate these changes in the new PCET Bill to better align with national priorities and improve the impact of the plans.

* The 2015 Higher Education (Wales) Act aimed to regulate institutions, safeguard public good, maintain fair access, and protect institutional autonomy, but its effectiveness in achieving these goals is subject to debate.
* The Minister for Education intends to supersede the 2015 Act with a new Post-Compulsory Education and Training (PCET) Bill, incorporating lessons learned and adapting to current circumstances.
* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) has expressed concerns about the Act's regulatory powers being inflexible and difficult to use, while the University of Wales has noted issues with the fee and access plans' bureaucratic nature and short time frame.
* The Minister is considering reforms to the fee and access plans, such as moving to longer-term, outcome-focused agreements, to better align with national priorities and improve their effectiveness.

• Kirsty Williams AM and Huw Morris attended the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.
• The committee questioned whether the 2015 Act has fulfilled all the Government's objectives and if it will be repealed or amended by the post-compulsory education and training Bill.
• Kirsty Williams acknowledged that the Act's strategic aims are still relevant but noted the need for updated legislation that is fit for the current and future context.
• The discussion highlighted concerns about the Act's effectiveness in aligning with national priorities and the potential for a new Bill to include national outcomes.
• The role of charitable status for institutions and the regulation of private providers were debated, with the possibility of maintaining charitable status in the new legislation.
• Questions were raised about the level of ambition in the Act and the need for more effective policy levers in the PCET Bill to align the sector with social, economic, and civic needs.
• The HE Act's powers of intervention were discussed, with some suggesting they are inflexible and difficult to use, while others found them adequate.
• The need for a graduated system of interventions and the importance of balancing institutional autonomy with regulatory requirements were emphasized.
• The role of fee and access plans in addressing access issues was questioned, with a preference for outcome agreements in the new legislation.
• Governance issues were highlighted, with a focus on the need for diversity and better understanding of governance responsibilities among board members.
• Concerns about the quality assurance framework and the potential for a single body were addressed, with assurances that the new framework would maintain high standards.
• The regulation of overseas providers and transnational education was discussed, with an emphasis on ensuring quality and protecting the sector's reputation.

• Questions on quality assurance, including the potential for a single quality assurance body, and the regulation of overseas providers were raised.
• The committee expressed interest in the post-legislative scrutiny of the Act and the future of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.

• Kirsty Williams AM and Huw Morris attended the Children, Young People and Education Committee for a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.

• The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015's objectives are being reviewed, with the intention of updating legislation to better align with current needs and future goals.
• The Minister for Education is committed to maintaining institutional autonomy while ensuring appropriate regulation and accountability for public funding and privileges.

* The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher education and further education institutions since the Brexit vote in 2016 to understand the potential impacts.

* The Welsh Government has been working with Universities Wales to access resources under the European transition fund to boost international marketing and maintain the strengths of the HE sector.

* The Welsh Government is concerned about the balance of the HE profile, with one high-tariff university showing growth in recruitment of EU students, while others are seeing a drop.
* The Welsh Government has allocated additional funding to HEFCW to deal with demographic changes and the initial implications of EU transition, and is working with universities to mitigate Brexit impacts.
* The Welsh Government has reached an agreement in principle to fund a Global Wales initiative to assist universities in targeting and beefing up international recruitment work.

• Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, along with their officials, attended the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education.
• The committee received assurances that the Welsh Government is working closely with higher education and further education institutions to prepare for Brexit, including visiting individual institutions to assess their readiness.
• The Cardiff University research, which was published with the Bevan Foundation, has been superseded by the Welsh Government's own research on the impact of Brexit on higher education, further education, and apprenticeship providers.
• The European transition team within the Welsh Government is coordinating efforts to prepare for Brexit, providing governance structure and leading discussions with the Department for Exiting the European Union and other relevant bodies.
• The Welsh Government has been engaging with the National Union of Students (NUS) and has been clear about the importance of maintaining open institutions, welcoming EU and international students, and valuing faculty from the EU.
• The Welsh Government is working with Universities Wales to access resources under the European transition fund to boost international marketing of the higher education sector and to support institutions in responding to the Reid review proposals.
• The Welsh Government has been proactive in addressing the potential impact of Brexit on student recruitment, particularly the drop in EU student applications, by acknowledging the change in funding policy and the need to market the strengths of the HE sector.
• The Welsh Government has allocated additional funding to HEFCW to deal with short-term implications arising from demographic changes and EU transition, and is providing PS3.5 million to Universities Wales for international work and recruitment.
• The Welsh Government is concerned about the sustainability of the higher education sector, particularly in light of the managed deficit and the uncertainty around funding for Diamond and Reid reviews.
• The Welsh Government is prioritizing the maintenance of learning opportunities under European Union funding in the further education sector, with a commitment to maintain the current level of resource if the UK Government keeps its promises.
• The Welsh Government is working with other departments within the Government to safeguard the interests of institutions and businesses affected by Brexit, focusing on regional skills partnerships and direct engagement with employers.

* The team discusses the routine for data collection, focusing on creating a system that understands user intentions and preferences.
* They aim to gather data on various tourist activities, such as visiting zoos, universities, and castles, to improve the system's linguistic capabilities.
* The team decides to limit the complexity of the data collection by focusing on a few types of places, aiming for more varied responses from participants.
* They consider adding temporal references to the tasks, allowing users to plan activities for different days or future visits.
* The system will be designed to handle simple requests initially, with the potential for more complex interactions as the project progresses.
* The team plans to review the collected data after ten subjects have participated, aiming to analyze interesting linguistic patterns and variations.
* They discuss the importance of collecting data on different aspects of tourist activities, such as sightseeing, meeting people, and running errands.
* The team agrees on the need to categorize user preferences, such as the urgency of visiting a place, the mode of transportation, and the time spent on activities.
* They consider the inclusion of a "socializing" category for activities that involve meeting people, recognizing the distinct nature of such interactions.
* The team acknowledges the challenge of inferring user preferences and plans to ask for clarification when necessary, balancing user input with system-driven decisions.

• The focus of the meeting was to discuss the design and implementation of a belief-net for a system that assists tourists in planning their trips.
• The team aimed to collect data from subjects to understand various tourist intentions and activities, focusing on tasks like visiting places, obtaining information, and running errands.
• They planned to review the collected data, consisting of ten-minute dialogues, in two weeks to analyze the linguistic constructions used by participants.
• The team considered creating categories of activities, such as sightseeing, meeting people, and doing business, to simplify the data collection process.
• Timing decisions were discussed, with options for immediate, later on the same tour, or on a future tour, to capture different planning scenarios.
• The system's planner would use parameters like mode of transportation, length of visit, and budget to make decisions, with the belief-net inferring these based on user input and context.
• Object information and user interest in details about the object were also considered, with scales for levels of interest proposed.
• The team agreed to proceed with the simplified data collection plan, aiming to gather more complex data in future iterations if necessary.

• The group discussed the targeting of the pupil development grant (PDG), with concerns raised about its blurring of eligibility and focus on low-attaining free school meal (FSM) pupils rather than FSM pupils specifically. 
• The Cabinet Secretary highlighted examples of good practice, such as schools using PDG for growth mindset training and a 'window on the world' bus to raise aspirations for more able and talented FSM pupils. 
• There was a debate on whether eligibility for free school meals remains the best measure for identifying pupils to target, with the Cabinet Secretary acknowledging the limitations but noting the absence of a better proxy. 
• The Cabinet Secretary mentioned ongoing work to improve PDG targeting, including the appointment of regional PDG advisers to spread good practice and discussions on flexibility and longer-term funding allocations.

* The group assesses the extent and condition that schools effectively utilize the pupil development grant (PDG).
* Schools are encouraged to use PDG for individual interventions targeting children eligible for free school meals.
* Universal interventions can also be employed if they disproportionately benefit free school meal recipients.
* PDG is used to support more able and talented students, including those eligible for free school meals.
* The eligibility for free school meals is considered the best proxy for identifying students to target with PDG.
* The Welsh Government is considering more flexible PDG allocation methods to provide longer-term projections for schools.
* Schools are advised to use the Sutton Trust toolkit for evidence-based interventions when spending PDG.
* The Welsh Government is evaluating the impact of PDG on attendance and engagement with education.
* PDG is used to reduce exclusions and improve the educational outcomes of children eligible for free school meals.

• The majority of schools are making well thought out and appropriate decisions on how to use PDG, according to the Cabinet Secretary.
• However, Estyn reported that only two-thirds of primary and secondary schools make effective use of the PDG.
• The usage of PDG is evolving over time, reflecting the journeys of schools from a low base to better understanding and application of evidence-based interventions.
• The Cabinet Secretary does not accept that some of the PDG funding is used to paper over funding cracks from elsewhere.
• PDG is being used to support attendance and engagement with education, with schools employing various initiatives like walking buses and staff outreach.
• The attainment gap between free-school-meal children and others widened in 2017, but the Cabinet Secretary emphasizes the direction of travel has been positive over the period of PDG implementation.
• The Cabinet Secretary is concerned about the disproportionate number of free-school-meal children subject to temporary exclusions and is working on strategies to reduce this.
• The impact of PDG on looked-after children's attainment is disappointing, leading to a review and a focus on better linked-up working between education and other government departments.
• The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges the need for a more sophisticated performance measure for schools, moving away from level 2 plus to better reflect the value added by schools for each individual child.
• The PDG for looked-after children is held at a regional level, with a focus on strategic deployment and capacity building, but there are concerns about the rapid turnover of children in schools.
• The Cabinet Secretary is considering adjusting eligibility for PDG to include children who have been looked-after or adopted at any point, not just those currently looked-after.
• The EAS consortium uses PDG as part of a broader approach targeting vulnerable learners, including those with adverse childhood experiences.
• The Cabinet Secretary is actively looking at ways to create a dataset for adopted children, considering data protection and sharing, to better track their educational outcomes.
• The latest data on looked-after children's attainment is extremely disappointing, leading to a review of the PDG's impact in this area and a focus on better integration between education and social services.
• The exclusion rates for looked-after children are over six times higher than for others, and the PDG is not specifically used for addressing exclusions, but the Cabinet Secretary emphasizes the need for a holistic approach to supporting these children's educational needs.

• The group discussed the targeted use of the pupil development grant (PDG), focusing on its effectiveness in targeting vulnerable learners, particularly those eligible for free school meals. 
• Concerns were raised about the clarity of eligibility criteria and the potential for the PDG to be used to address funding gaps in core budgets. The Cabinet Secretary emphasized the importance of maintaining focus on free school meals as a proxy for need, while acknowledging the need for continuous improvement and better consistency in PDG usage across schools.
• The impact of PDG on attendance and engagement was also discussed, with examples highlighting proactive approaches in schools to improve attendance rates, especially for free school meal-eligible children. The need for a multi-agency approach to address exclusions and support vulnerable learners was acknowledged.
• The attainment gap at GCSE level was noted to have widened in 2017, despite previous narrowing trends. The Cabinet Secretary attributed this to various factors, including changes in exam content and the performance variability across different schools and cities. Efforts were made to understand the reasons behind this trend and to develop new performance measures that better reflect educational outcomes for all students.

• The PDG for looked-after children is held at a regional level, with a focus on strategic deployment and capacity building, but concerns are being raised about its visibility and effectiveness.
• The eligibility criteria for PDG are under review, considering whether to adjust it to include children who have been looked after or adopted at any point, not just those currently looked after.

• The exclusion rates for looked-after children are disproportionately high, with the PDG used to support strategies aimed at reducing exclusions and improving school attendance.
• The Schools Challenge Cymru program had a mixed bag of performance, with some schools making progress due to leadership changes and effective support from challenge advisers.

• Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, the head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, were welcomed by the Children, Young People and Education Committee for scrutiny on the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy.
• The strategy is an all-age approach, with a focus on children and young people due to the high prevalence of overweight and obesity among adults and its consequences.
• Engagement with children and young people has been conducted through various forums, including a schoolgirl's personal account and visits to schools.
• The Minister for health was advised not to set a target for reducing obesity in children, but that a target could be beneficial and should be considered in the consultation process.
• The level of investment needed to implement the plan is uncertain, but it could range from PS8 million to PS10 million per year, with a need to evaluate existing programs for better effectiveness.
• The sugar levy consequentials are less than anticipated, with PS56 million expected over two years, which could be used to fund initiatives aimed at reducing childhood obesity.
• Partnership working is crucial for the strategy's success, with a need for leadership, drive, and alignment across public services boards and other sectors.
• Data on childhood obesity is available through the child measurement program, but there is a need for more longitudinal data to better understand the issue.
• The plan commits to reviewing the clinical obesity pathway, with Public Health Wales tasked to conduct the review before the final strategy is launched in October.
• The draft plan acknowledges the importance of the first 1,000 days for shaping healthy behaviors, but lacks new proposals to address the influence of family and parents on children's healthy weight behaviors.
• The Welsh Government is considering taking bolder action to support low-income families in eating healthily, recognizing the link between economic success and health success.

* Dr Frank Atherton confirmed that the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' strategy is aimed at both the current and future generations, focusing on preventing overweight and obesity.
* Engagement with children and young people has been conducted through various forums, including a schoolgirl's personal account and school visits.
* The Chief Medical Officer is open to considering targets for reducing childhood obesity, balancing deliverability with challenge.
* The level of investment needed to implement the plan depends on the strategy's goals and outcomes, with a potential range of PS8 million to PS10 million annually.
* The Welsh Government is using the sugar levy's consequentials to fund initiatives, with the amount received being less than initially anticipated.
* Partnership working is crucial for the strategy's success, requiring alignment across public services, industry, communities, and the public.
* The consultation process will determine the need for legislation, with questions on restricting price promotions and banning energy drinks included.
* The planning system could be used to restrict hot food takeaways around schools, but its effectiveness is uncertain.
* Improving community sport infrastructure, including in schools, is seen as a way to increase accessibility for the wider public.
* The Healthy and Sustainable Preschool Scheme is being evaluated, with expectations for improvements in standards and implementation.
* The strategy development board is considering the role of local leadership in education, particularly in relation to the new curriculum and teacher accountability.
* The importance of making every contact count is recognized, with a need for health professionals to support individuals with weight issues.
* The Welsh Government acknowledges the challenges in availability of people to refer to for support, advocating for a transformed primary care system.

* Engagement with children and young people has been conducted through discussions with school groups and visits to schools, with plans for further consultation.
* The discussion included the potential for setting targets to reduce childhood obesity, with the view that targets should balance deliverability with challenge.
* The strategy's leadership and partnership working were discussed, with a focus on the need for strong political commitment and local ownership to drive the initiative effectively.

* The meeting summary highlights the team's successful development of a new remote control prototype, focusing on its design, features, and marketability.
* The prototype, shaped like a snail, incorporates a speech recognition feature, bright colors, and soft buttons, aiming for a trendy, child-friendly design. It also includes an oversized holder for easy storage.

• The team discussed the impact of using PDA microphones in recordings, noting that while it led to reduced latency, it also introduced noise at five hertz, affecting the quality of the audio. They considered changing the input box capacitor or applying a digital filter to mitigate the issue but decided to filter the data post-collection instead.

• PhD F presented the results of integrating new filters, downsampling, upsampling, and on-line normalization into the system. While there were no significant improvements, the system didn't worsen in performance. The team is considering further experiments, such as increasing the number of mixtures per state in the models, to enhance the system's performance.

• The group discussed the weighting of improvements in the final score calculation for the evaluation system. • The meeting discussed the progress of various research projects, including spectral subtraction, Wiener filtering, and subspace techniques for noise reduction in speech recognition systems.
• PhD B presented on Wiener filtering, noting that a single-stage Wiener filter improved baseline performance by 30%, but a two-stage approach with smoothing improved performance to 56.5% on SpeechDat-Car dataset.
• PhD D discussed spectral subtraction, incorporating an overestimation factor to adjust noise spectrum subtraction based on signal-to-noise ratio, achieving 3.8%, 9.1%, and 16.5% word error rates on Italian, Finnish, and Spanish datasets respectively.
• Professor C raised concerns about negative values resulting from spectral subtraction and suggested alternatives like smoothing or thresholding, while also questioning the impact of smoothing on musical noise.
• The team considered the use of smoothing techniques to mitigate issues like musical noise and improve overall system performance, with some methods showing promise in enhancing recognition accuracy.

* The committee welcomed the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales and Dr. David Blaney as chief executive, along with Bethan Owen, director of institutional engagement.

* EU student applications to Welsh institutions decreased by 8% compared to a 2% increase in England, possibly due to changes in student support arrangements.
* The main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, capital expenditure, and the uncertainty of English funding reforms.
* Brexit has led to a decrease in EU and international student applications, affecting fee income and potentially the attractiveness of Welsh institutions.
* Universities are planning for various scenarios, including reduced EU student recruitment, by revising fee and access plans and seeking additional funding sources.
* The sector is working collectively to promote Wales as an attractive study destination and advocating for continued access to EU funding programs like Horizon 2020.
* The funding council monitors institutions' financial forecasts and sustainability, challenging assumptions that do not align with expectations.
* The sector is committed to maintaining student mobility and international engagement, despite potential changes to programs like Erasmus+.
* The council works closely with the National Union of Students in Wales and has measures in place to protect student interests in case of provider difficulties.
* The quality of the student experience is affected by the richness of the student body, which may diminish with a reduction in EU student numbers.
* The uncertainty of Brexit funding implications remains a concern, with the sector running deficit budgets in anticipation of the Diamond funding release.
* The committee discussed the potential impact of Brexit on research funding, collaboration networks, and the ability to attract charitable sector research funding.
* The council is addressing the barriers to securing UK research council funding, focusing on increasing investment, critical mass, and engagement with research councils.
* The committee noted the importance of maintaining research quality, impact, and critical mass in Wales to attract more research funding and enhance international collaboration.

• The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment of children to protect their rights and ensure they have the same protection as adults.
• The Bill is based on the principle that it is wrong for a bigger person to hit a smaller person, and it seeks to clarify the law by removing the defence of reasonable punishment.
• The Welsh Government is committed to updating the law to reflect the rights of children and to send a clear message that physical punishment is not acceptable.
• The Bill is part of a wider package of support for children and parents, including the "Parenting. Give it time" campaign and universal services provided by local government, health, education, social services, social justice, and the third sector.
• The Government is working with agencies such as the police, the police and crime commissioners, the Crown Prosecution Service, and the Association of Directors of Social Services Cymru to prepare for the implementation of the Bill.
• The implementation group has set up four work streams to address issues such as parenting advice and support, data collection, operations, procedures, and processes, and out-of-court disposals and diversions.
• The Bill is expected to remove the defence of reasonable punishment, which could lead to a small increase in reporting of incidents, but social services and other agencies are prepared to handle the workload.
• The Welsh Government is committed to a high-intensity awareness-raising campaign to educate the public about the Bill and its implications.
• The Bill's impact on resources is uncertain, but the Government is working with organizations such as the CPS, CAFCASS Cymru, and social services to ensure they are prepared for any changes.
• The Bill's human rights considerations have been carefully assessed, and the Government believes the legislation is necessary to protect children's rights and freedoms.
• The Bill's impact on the public's understanding of the current law is significant, with 58% of the public already believing the law does not allow physical punishment of children.
• The Welsh Government is committed to a significant public awareness campaign to ensure the Bill's effectiveness, although the necessity of a duty on the face of the Bill is still under consideration.
• The Bill's implementation will depend on the successful collaboration between various agencies, including social services, the police, and the Crown Prosecution Service, to ensure a smooth transition.

• The Welsh Government has outlined principles for reopening schools, focusing on safety, well-being, and clear communication with stakeholders.
• Vulnerable children and those of key workers continue to attend hubs, with numbers increasing, but still representing a small percentage of the total student population.
• The Welsh Government is working on plans to support children's mental health and well-being, including additional funding for school counseling, and addressing digital access disparities for continuity of learning.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, were welcomed by Lynne Neagle AM for an evidence session on the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
• The five principles guiding the decision on when schools might reopen were outlined by Kirsty Williams AM, emphasizing the need for safety, clear communication, and reliance on medical and scientific advice.
• The principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, with universities being independent institutions but kept informed of the approaches being taken.
• The Welsh Government is working on a four-nation basis with counterparts in Northern Ireland, Scotland, and England, and looking beyond the UK for best international evidence on education during the pandemic.
• The smooth operation of school hubs, with a focus on health and safety, is being managed by providing guidance to local authorities and reporting any concerns.
• Testing for COVID-19 among school staff has been limited, with 15 teachers tested and two positive results, but the Welsh Government has issued new guidance encouraging testing for those exhibiting symptoms.
• Vulnerable children and those of key workers are attending school hubs, with numbers doubling since the start of the traditional summer term, and the Welsh Government is working to increase attendance where appropriate.
• The Welsh Government has allocated PS1.25 million to support school counseling, with the funds being used to increase and ramp up services, including remote counseling and family therapy, in line with social distancing rules.
• The continuity-of-learning plan addresses digital disadvantage, with the Welsh Government working with local authorities to ensure all children have access to necessary hardware and connectivity for digital learning.

• The Welsh Government has outlined principles for reopening schools, focusing on safety, well-being, and clear communication with stakeholders.
• Schools will reopen gradually, prioritizing vulnerable children and those of key workers, but not all children will return immediately.
• The Welsh Government is working on a phased return to education, considering the advice of medical and scientific experts.
• The principles for reopening schools also aim to ensure confidence among parents, staff, and students, based on evidence and information.
• These principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, with universities being independent institutions.
• The Welsh Government is actively considering the impact on particular children, including those with additional learning needs and emotional/mental health issues.
• The Welsh Government is allocating additional funding to support mental health and well-being, including remote counseling and therapy services.
• The Welsh Government is addressing digital inequality by providing hardware and connectivity to students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds.
• The Welsh Government is communicating with parents on expectations for home learning, emphasizing support and flexibility.
• The Welsh Government is working closely with local authorities to ensure all students have access to learning resources.
• The Welsh Government is providing guidance and resources for year 13 and year 12 students to prepare for further education and university.
• The Welsh Government is extending the moratorium on unconditional university offers to support the higher education sector.
• The Welsh Government is maintaining student support payments for those who have returned home, adjusting for lower living costs.
• The Welsh Government is in discussions with NUS Wales and counterparts across the UK to support students affected by the pandemic.
• The Welsh Government is releasing funding earlier to HEFCW, aiming for flexibility in how institutions use the resources.
• The Welsh Government is considering a four-nation approach to support the higher education sector through the pandemic.

* Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, were welcomed by Lynne Neagle AM for an evidence session on the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
* The five principles guiding the decision on when schools might reopen were outlined, emphasizing safety, well-being, communication, evidence-based decisions, and operational considerations.
* The principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, with universities being independent institutions.
* The Welsh Government is working on a four-nation basis with counterparts in Northern Ireland, Scotland, and England, and looking at international evidence for best practices.
* Testing is crucial for planning future phases, but it is not imminent that schools will reopen.
* Vulnerable children and those of key workers are prioritized for school attendance, with numbers increasing since the start of the traditional summer term.
* 5.6% of the teaching population works in school hubs, and approximately 85% of children attending are from key worker families.
* 15 teachers have been tested for COVID-19, with 2 positive results, and the Welsh Government has issued new guidance for critical workers.
* The Welsh Government is working with local authorities to facilitate more vulnerable children attending school hubs, recognizing the challenges and complexities involved.
* Additional funding of PS1.25 million is allocated for school counseling, with the possibility of remote support and flexibility in service delivery.

* The Welsh Government has outlined principles for reopening schools, focusing on safety, well-being, and clear communication with stakeholders.
* The education system is currently supporting vulnerable children and those of key workers through school hubs, with plans to increase engagement for more vulnerable students.

* The Welsh Government is developing plans to repurpose schools, focusing on supporting vulnerable children, children of key workers, and those eligible for free school meals.
* Schools will play a crucial role in providing a safe and secure environment for children of front-line responders, with plans being finalized in collaboration with local authorities.
* The new purpose of schools will also include activities for children with additional learning needs, with the aim of safeguarding these children and ensuring continuity of learning.
* The Welsh Government is working to ensure that all maintained schools have access to digital tools for distance learning through the Hwb digital learning platform, including virtual classrooms and video conferencing facilities.
* The decision to cancel summer exams was made based on the clear advice from Qualifications Wales, with plans to award grades to year 11 and 13 students using a modulated system that maintains fairness and equity.

• The Welsh Government is developing plans to repurpose schools, focusing on supporting vulnerable children, providing continuity of learning, and assisting key workers. Immediate attention is on the needs of children of healthcare workers, free school meals recipients, and those with additional learning needs.

• The new school purpose will involve schools functioning as safe havens for children of essential workers, providing meals, and offering activities that cater to the age range of children, potentially including those up to age 16. The plans aim to be adaptable, considering evolving public health advice and the potential for changing circumstances.

• The Welsh Government has made the decision to close all schools from tomorrow for statutory education provision due to the COVID-19 pandemic, prioritizing public health and the safety of pupils and staff.
• The new purpose of schools will be to support and safeguard vulnerable children, including those of key workers, and to provide continuity of learning, especially for those eligible for free school meals and those with additional learning needs.
• Schools will be expected to plan for delivery post-Easter and to develop emergency responses for the immediate situation, with a focus on providing a planned set of activities for children of key workers and vulnerable children.
• The Welsh Government is working with local authorities and schools to ensure that the new arrangements are operationalized effectively, with a particular emphasis on safeguarding and continuity of learning.
• The decision to cancel summer exams has been made to ensure fairness and equity for students, with plans to award grades based on a range of available information, including teacher evaluations and externally verified work.
• The Welsh Government is committed to maintaining the rhythm of an exams day in August, despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, and is working with Qualifications Wales and the WJEC to operationalize this decision.
• The Welsh Government is also considering the potential closures of colleges and universities, with ongoing conversations with these institutions to ensure the safety and well-being of students and staff, and to provide support for vulnerable learners.
• Universities have been encouraged to move as much of their learning online as possible, and the Bill provides the Welsh Government with more powers of intervention in both the FE and HE sectors.
• The Welsh Government is working to ensure that student maintenance payments continue as normal, and that there are no disruptions to the EMA for students who are entitled to it.
• The mental health and well-being of staff and learners across educational settings are being supported through various online platforms and services, including the Meic website and NHS counseling services.
• The Welsh Government is considering the suspension of processes for additional learning needs pupils who are waiting for outcomes of referrals, acknowledging the massive compromise in delivering business as usual.
• The emergency legislation will provide the Welsh Government with powers to temporarily close schools or other educational institutions, childcare premises, and to give temporary continuity directions.
• The powers also include flexibility to relax requirements around ratios in childcare settings, and to be able to direct resources and staff to other institutions as needed.
• The insurance industry's response to the government's directions is problematic, as insurance companies are not paying out in cases where the government has directed closures or cancellations.

* The Welsh Government has made the decision to close all schools from tomorrow for statutory education provision due to the COVID-19 pandemic, prioritizing public health and the safety of pupils and staff.
* The purpose of schools will now shift to support vulnerable children, including those receiving free school meals, and children of key workers, with plans being developed in collaboration with local authorities.
* The Welsh Government is working on a system to ensure ongoing provision for vulnerable children and those who need continuity of learning, aiming for seamless support during the crisis.
* The decision to cancel summer exams has been made to ensure fairness and equity for students, with arrangements being developed to award grades based on a range of information available.
* Year 11 and 13 students will receive grades to help them make decisions about their future, with a focus on maintaining standards through a modulated system across the UK.
* Universities have welcomed the approach to handling the lack of exams, with ongoing discussions about how to incorporate the awarded grades into university admissions and enrolment processes.
* Colleges and universities are moving as much of their learning online as possible, with safety nets in place for the most vulnerable learners, and support mechanisms are being developed to address the mental health and well-being of students.

• The Welsh Government has made the decision to close all schools from tomorrow for statutory education provision due to the COVID-19 pandemic, prioritizing public health and the safety of pupils and staff.
